stream_context.summary: Kaze prototypes and refines a “space-plantation” side section in the Cosmic Colony level: adding bumpers, crops, glowing platform borders, spring re-skins, a water-tank set-piece and alternative routes for speedrunners and novices while testing performance on real N64 hardware.

development_findings.summary: The new area uses bumper springs to traverse a plantation in space; half the plantation still needs modelling.
development_findings.quote: “So the idea with this area here, you use these bumpers to get around the plantation. And I still need to make half the plantation.”

development_findings.summary: All platforms will receive glowing outlines so edges stand out against the galaxy backdrop.
development_findings.quote: “I'm going to have glowing outlines on all the platforms in the end.”

development_findings.summary: Low-poly crops are planned as ‘green lumps arranged in lines’, possibly with the same glow shader used elsewhere.
Casino-rainbow springs were recoloured to metallic hues and matching colour-scroll to fit the plantation theme.
development_findings.quote: “I think the color scroll at the bottom has to change to be less rainbow and more fitting with the hues we present here.”

development_findings.summary: A performance test on real N64 yielded ~43 FPS; dense plant geometry currently hurts speed, and render distance still needs tuning.
development_findings.quote: “43 FPS. Ooh, it doesn't like all these plants here.”

development_findings.summary: Backwards Long Jump causes a reproducible crash due to an infinite loop; Kaze must ‘explicitly support’ BLJ in code.
development_findings.quote: “Sometimes people say that PLJ is gone in this game… My fucking game crashed.”

development_findings.summary: Level intentionally includes speedrun shortcuts (PLJ over gap, diagonal wall-jumps). New ‘novice’ platform added so casual players aren’t forced into janky jumps.
development_findings.quote: “Giving people the freedom to choose isn't that bad.”

development_findings.summary: Skybox is a camera-followed cube with adjustable parallax (e.g., 100 % for space, 95 % for oil rig) — cheaper than vanilla backgrounds.
Water-tank set-piece will use a CPU-generated, very slow ‘still water’ texture with darker rim shading.
development_findings.quote: “I think we need a dynamic CPU-generated texture… something very slow-moving.”

development_findings.summary: Story beats will be designed after gameplay; current focus is fun platforming, not narrative linkage.
development_findings.quote: “We haven't really planned the story yet. I think it's better to just put together some gameplay first.”

context_findings.summary: Kaze floated a 30-day, 12-hour-a-day ‘build a full hack live’ stream where donations extend the schedule; proceeds would go to his bank account, not charity.
context_findings.quote: “The more people donate, the higher quality the hack is going to be… I'm not doing 30 days of working 15 hours a day for charity.”

context_findings.summary: He wants Return to Yoshi’s Island to stand alone as a ‘real game’, pushing back against rom-hack culture that treats hacks as disposable mods.
context_findings.quote: “I want to make sure that this ROM hack is also playable as a normal game without the context of Mario 64.”

context_findings.summary: Streaming exhausts him; constant chat questions frustrate him, yet he values live feedback.
context_findings.quote: “Guys, why do you ask me so many questions today? That's my least favorite thing to happen ever.”

context_findings.summary: He injured his back doing deadlifts and has daily meetings (e.g., Banjo-Kazooie x Mario64 project), limiting stream frequency.
Plans to open-source the game eventually; leaked code would only mean people play an unfinished version.
context_findings.quote: “I'm planning to open source this game anyway, so there's little point in leaking it.”

key_stories.title: BLJ Crash Bug
key_stories.summary: While testing a speedrun shortcut, Kaze discovered that performing a BLJ consistently crashes the game.
key_stories.challenge: BLJ code enters an infinite loop, freezing the emulator and N64.
key_stories.process: Reproduced the crash, confirmed it’s inside custom BLJ handling, and noted need for explicit support.
key_stories.outcome: Issue isolated; Kaze plans to patch BLJ so the technique remains usable without crashes.
key_stories.key_quote: “It's clearly something in the PLJ code itself causing an infinite loop somewhere.”

key_stories.title: Making a Janky Jump Fair
key_stories.summary: A required diagonal wall-jump felt awkward for casual players.
key_stories.challenge: Jump was ‘jank’ and risked blocking less-skilled users.
key_stories.process: Tested multiple routes, added a small intermediate platform and kept advanced shortcuts intact.
key_stories.outcome: Section now accommodates both newbies (safe hop) and speedrunners (long-jump/BLJ).
key_stories.key_quote: “I don't want the player to do a jank jump like this.”
